fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_subsection_title: DECLARATION OF ASSETS AND LIABILITIES/OATH OF MEMBERS
fields.rule_details:
Every person elected to the House shall before taking his seat, declare his assets and liabilities in accordance with the Code of Conduct and subsequently take and subscribe before the Speaker of the House, the Oath of Allegiance and the Oath of Membership; but a Member may before taking the Oath, take part in the election of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House.

The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House shall declare their assets and liabilities in the manner prescribed by the Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria and subsequently take and subscribe to the Oath of Allegiance, the Oath of Membership and the Oath of Office as aforesaid before the Clerk of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_subsection_title: ELIGIBILITY OF MR. SPEAKER AND DEPUTY SPEAKER
fields.rule_details: For a Member to be eligible to be the Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House, he must have legislative experience as a Member of the Edo State House of Assembly.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The business of the House shall be conducted in English but the House may in addition to English conduct its business in one or more languages spoken in the State as the House may by resolution, approve.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Mr. Speaker shall allocate a seat to each Member. A Member may only speak from the seat allocated to him provided that Mr. speaker may change the allocation from time to time.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
Whenever the House shall stand adjourned sine die and it is presented to Mr. Speaker by the Majority Leader of the House that the House shall meet on a certain day at a certain time, the Speaker shall give notice accordingly and the House shall meet at the date and time stated in the notice.

Whenever the House stands adjourned either to a date fixed by the Rule of the House or to a date determined in accordance with paragraph (1) of this rule and it is represented by the Majority Leader of the House to Mr. Speaker that the Public interest requires that the House should meet on an earlier or a later day or time than that on which it stands adjourned, the Speaker may give notice of the date and time stated in the notice.

Whenever the Speaker shall have given notice in accordance with either of the two preceding paragraphs, the Clerk shall communicate the terms of the notice to each Member.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The House shall sit for a period of not less than 181 days in a year.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The House shall sit on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays or any other day, as the House may by Resolution approve.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The House shall meet on any of its sitting days at 10:00 am unless the Speaker directs otherwise.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The House shall not adjourn except in pursuance of a Resolution to that effect, the Motion of which may be made by any Member of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In any sitting of the House, Mr. Speaker shall preside.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
Mr. Speaker shall take the Chair on every legislative day precisely at the hour to which the house shall have adjourned at the last sitting and immediately call the Members to order.

Mr. Speaker, having examined the Votes and Proceedings of the last day's sitting and approved same, shall announce to the House, his approval. This shall be deemed to have been agreed to, subject to a vote of any Member, which vote, if decided in the affirmative, shall not be subject to Motion to reconsider.

It shall be in order to offer by way of a Motion, that the Votes and Proceedings be read only if the Speaker's approval of the Votes and proceedings is not agreed to and such Motion shall be determined without debate and shall not be subject to a Motion to reconsider.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: He shall preserve order and decorum and in case of disturbance or disorderly conduct in the galleries or the lobby, may cause same to be cleared.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: He shall have general control, except as provided by the Rule of Law, of the Chamber of the House and the corridors and passages.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: He shall sign all acts, addresses, resolutions, writs, warrants, and subpoena of or issued by order of the House, and decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal by any Member, on which appeal no Member shall speak more than once, unless by permission of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Speaker shall control the House as stipulated in the "Rules of Debate".

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Any question proposed for decision in the House shall be determined by the required majority votes of the Members present; and the Speaker or Chairman (if in Committee of the Whole) shall cast a vote whenever necessary to avoid an equality of votes but shall not vote in other cases.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: He shall interpret the Rules.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In the absence of the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker shall perform all the duties and functions of the Speaker.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_subsection_title: ABSENCE OF MR. SPEAKER AND DEPUTY SPEAKER
fields.rule_details: In the absence of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House, a Member of the House, preferably the next most senior Member of the Principal Officers Council, as the House may by a simple majority elect for that purpose, shall preside.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
Leaders in the House shall be:
  1. Majority Leader
  2. Minority Leader
  3. Chief Whip
  4. Deputy Leader
  5. Deputy Whip
Members of each party in the House shall nominate their Leader.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: After due Notice of the House, each party shall have the right to change its Leader and other assigned officers, provided that the change is made by the Members of the Party to the House themselves and is acceptable to the majority of the Members.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
The Majority Leader shall be a Member nominated from the party with the highest number of members. His functions shall be:
  1. To lead the business of the House.
  2. To manage the legislative schedule of the House.
  3. To liaise with the Committee Chairman and other functionaries of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Clerk shall, at the commencement of the first sitting of the House, call the Members to order, proceed to call the roll of Members in alphabetical order, pending the election of a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: At the opening of each day's proceedings, the Clerk shall distribute to Members, a paper to be known as the Order Paper setting forth the business of the day.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Clerk shall keep minutes of the proceedings of the House and of Committees of the Whole House and shall circulate a copy of such minutes to be known as the Votes and Proceedings on the day following each sitting of the House or as soon after as possible.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Votes and Proceedings shall record all decisions of the House and shall be signed by the Speaker.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In the case of divisions of the House or Committee of the Whole House, the Votes and Proceedings shall include the numbers voting for and against the questions and the names of Members so voting.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Clerk shall prepare from day to day, and keep an Order Book showing all business appointed for any future day, and notices of questions or Motions which have been set down for a future day or an early day if no particular day has been selected. The Order Book shall be open for the inspection of Members at all reasonable times at the office of the Clerk or at the Table.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Clerk shall be responsible for the custody of the Votes, Records, Bills and other documents laid before the House, which shall be open to inspection by Members of the House, and other persons under such arrangements as may be sanctioned by Mr. Speaker.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: It shall be the duty of the Sergeant-at-Arms to attend sittings of the House, to maintain order under the direction of Mr. Speaker or Chairman, and pending the election of a Speaker or Deputy Speaker under the direction of the Clerk, execute the commands of the House and all processes issued by its authority thereof, directed to him by Mr. Speaker.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The symbol of his Office shall be the Mace which shall be borne by him while enforcing order on the floor.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Door-Keeper shall enforce strictly, the rules relating to the privileges of the Chamber.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: He shall allow no person to enter into the rooms reserved for Members of the House during its sittings and fifteen minutes before the hour of meeting of the House each day, he shall see that the floor is cleared of all persons except those privileged to remain, and kept so.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The door-Keeper shall have the duty until ten minutes after adjournment of ensuring that no visitor allowed by the Speaker or any other presiding officer into the Chamber of the House has on himself a camera of any description whatsoever, for the purpose of taking photographs, monitoring or recording the proceedings of the House, neither shall such visitors bear firearms.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The quorum of the House shall be one-third of all Members of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
If any Member draws the attention of Mr. Speaker to the fact that a quorum of the House is not formed or if, from the number of Members taking part in a division, including those Members who declined to vote, it appears that a quorum is not formed, Mr. Speaker shall direct strangers to withdraw and cause Members to be summoned as if for a division.

At the expiration of two minutes from the order to strangers to withdraw, Mr. Speaker shall count the House and if a quorum is not formed, shall adjourn the House forthwith.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
If notice be taken in a Committee of the Whole House that a quorum is not formed, the Chairman shall follow the course pursued by Mr. Speaker in accordance with paragraph (2) of this Rule. If he ascertains that less than one half of all Members are present, the Chairman shall leave the Chair and the House shall be resumed, whereupon Mr. Speaker shall count.

The House shall again resolve itself into Committee but if a quorum is not formed, Mr. Speaker shall Adjourn the House forthwith.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: If, from the number of Members taking part in a division, including those Members who declined to vote, it appears that a quorum is not formed, the Division shall be invalid and the business then under consideration shall stand over until the next sitting while Mr. Speaker shall count the House as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this Rule. If a quorum is then formed the next business shall be entered upon.

Unless the House otherwise directs, the business of each sitting day shall be transacted in the following order:
  1. Formal entry of Mr. Speaker;
  2. Prayer;
  3. Roll call of Members;
  4. Approval of votes and Proceedings;
  5. Oath of Allegiance and the Oath of Membership of New Members;
  6. Messages from the Governor;
  7. Other Announcements by Mr. Speaker;
  8. Petitions;
  9. Matters of Urgent Public Importance;
  10. Personal Explanations;
  11. Order of the day; and
  12. Adjournment.

Mr. Speaker shall immediately after prayers or as soon as any Member has taken the Oath of Allegiance, read to the House or cause to be read any Message addressed to the House by the Governor of Edo State of Nigeria.
A message from the Governor, if presented to the House by Mr. Speaker, may be brought up at any time before the commencement or at close of public business, and shall be considerd upon a future day.
A Petition may only be presented to the House by a Member, who shall affix his name at the beginning thereof.

A Member presenting a petition shall confine himself to a brief statement of the parties from whom it came, the number of signatures attached to it and the material allegations contained in it and to reading the prayer of such petition.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: No debate shall be allowed on such Petition, but it may be read by the Clerk, if required

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: All Petitions shall be ordered without question put to lie upon the Table. Such Petitions shall stand referred to the Public Petitions Committee.

fields.rule_section_title: MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND SITTINGS OF THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
No Member may present to the House a Petition signed by himself, except it is certified by the Clerk as being in accordance with the following rules
  1. Every Petition must be properly addressed to the House, respectful, decorous and temperate in language and must conclude with a prayer setting forth the general object of the petitioner.
  2. Every Petition must be signed by at least one person on every sheet on which the Petition is written
  3. If signatures are affixed to sheets other than that containing the Petition itself, such sheet, shall carry at their head the prayer of the petition.
  4. Signatures or marks will not be counted unless, in the case off marks they are witnessed, and unless in both cases they are followed by the addresses of the persons signing or making a mark, Such signatures must by written upon, and not pasted or otherwise attached to each of the sheets on which the petition itself is written. A Corporation should sign a petition with its common seal.

The matter for discussion shall, if possible, be referred to Mr. Speaker before the commencement of the dayÆs sitting, and Mr. Speaker shall refuse the claim unless he is satisfied that the matter is definite and urgent.
Not more than one such Motion may be made at the sitting.

By the indulgence of the House and the leave of Mr. Speaker, a Member may make a personal explanation although there be no question before the House, but no controversial matter may be brought forward nor may debate arise upon the explanation.  The terms of the proposed statement shall be submitted in extenso to Mr. Speaker when his leave to make it is sought.
An Order of the Day is a Bill or other matters which the House has ordered to be taken into consideration on a particular day. An earlier day cannot be substituted for the day so appointed.
Orders of the day not reached before the end of sitting or appointed for a day on which the House does not sit shall be set down for a later date to be determined by the Rules and Business Committee.
No Rule shall be suspended except by a vote of two-thirds of the Members voting, a quorum being present.

When a Motion to suspend the Rules has been submitted to the House, it shall be in order, before the final vote is taken thereon, to debate the proposition to be voted upon for twenty minutes.  One-half of such time would be given to debate in favour of, and one-half to debate in opposition to such proposition and the same right of debate shall be allowed whenever the previous question has been ordered on any proposition on which there has been no debate.

On any Legislative day in which the Speaker entertains to suspend the Rules and pass Bills or Resolutions, he may announce to the House, in his discretion, before entertaining the first such Motions that he will postpone further proceedings on each of such Motions on which a recorded vote or the æAyesÆ and æNaysÆ is ordered or on which the vote is objected to until:
  1. all such Motions on that legislative day have been entertained and any debate thereon concluded, with the question having been put and determined on each of such Motions on which the taking of the vote will not be postponed, or
  2. the next legislative day with the question having been put and determined on each Motion on which the taking of the vote will not be postponed;
  3. Where the Speaker has postponed vote pursuant to paragraph 3(a) of this Rule, when the last of all Motions on that legislative day to suspend the Rules and pass Bills or Resolutions has been entertained, and any debate therein concluded, the Speaker shall put the question on each Motion which further proceedings were postponed, in the Order in which that Motion was entertained.

Where the Speaker has postponed vote pursuant to paragraph 3(b) of this Rule, on the next legislative day, the Speaker shall put as unfinished business on which further proceedings were postponed, in the order in which that Motion was entertained.

At any time after the vote on the question has been taken on the first Motion on which the Speaker has postponed further proceedings under this paragraph, the Speaker may in his discretion, reduce to not less than five minutes, the period of time within which a recorded vote on the question may be taken on any or all of the additional Motions on which the Speaker has postponed further proceedings under this paragraph.

Unless the Rules otherwise direct,Notice shall be Motions given of any Motion or Amendment which it is proposed to move with the exception of the following:
  1. A Motion or Amendment made or offered in Committee of the Whole House.
  2. A Motion for the Adjournment of the House or of any debate.
  3. A Motion that the Report of a Select Committee be referred to a Committee of the House.
  4. A Motion for the withdrawal of strangers.
  5. A Motion arising out of the business of the day made immediately after that business or disposed of and made before any fresh matter is entered into.
  6. An Amendment to a Motion which has been moved without Notice either under this Rule or Rule 26.
Notice must be written and signed.

All Notices of Motions must be submitted to the Speaker at the following period:
  1. On a day on which the House is sitting.
  2. On a day when the House is not sitting between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3.00 p.m. except on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays.

The Speaker shall cause such Notices of Motions to be numbered and published in the Schedule of ôNotice of Motionsö and assigned to the relevant Committee not later than seven days after the publication in the Schedule.

The Committee shall examine the substance of all Motions referred to it and if approved for presentation to the House, shall forward its recommendation to the Rules and Business Committee for scheduling.

All Notices of Amendments to Motions must be given to the Speaker not later than five days after the publication of the Schedule. The Speaker shall cause such Amendments to be forwarded to the relevant Committee.
Amendments proposed to any Motion or Bill under consideration in the House or a Committee shall only be in order if they are relevant to the question or matter then under discussion.
An Amendment proposed to any Amendment shall only be in order if it be relevant to that Amendment.
The question on any Motion or Amendment shall not be proposed from the Chair in the House, unless it shall have been seconded, but in a Committee, a Seconder shall not be required.

fields.rule_subsection_title: METHOD OF PUTTING THE QUESTION ON AMENDMENT
fields.rule_details: Upon an Amendment to insert or add another word or words, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall state the	Amendment and propose the question thereon in the 	form ôThat those words be there inserted (or added)ö.

fields.rule_subsection_title: METHOD OF PUTTING THE QUESTION ON AMENDMENT
fields.rule_details: Upon an Amendment to leave out words, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall state the Amendment and propose the question thereon in the form ôThat those words be left outö.

fields.rule_subsection_title: METHOD OF PUTTING THE QUESTION ON AMENDMENT
fields.rule_details: Upon an Amendment to leave out words, and insert others instead, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall first state the words to be left out, and put the question thereon in the form ôThat those words be left outö, and if the question be agreed to, shall then state the words proposed to be inserted and put the question thereon in the form, ôThat those words be then insertedö.

A  Motion  or  an  Amendment  may  be  withdrawn, at the request of the mover, by leave of the House or Committee, before the commencement of debate.  A Motion or an Amendment so withdrawn may be made again but in the case of a Motion, Notice is required.
If an Amendment has been proposed to a question, the original Motion cannot be withdrawn until the Amendment has been disposed of.

Notice shall not be dispensed with in the case of a Motion  or  in  respect  of  any  other  proceeding for 
which Notice is required except with the consent of Mr. Speaker and the general assent of the Members present.
A Member shall not read his speech save if he is moving a Motion or presenting a Bill.
A Member may however, read short extracts from books or papers in support of his argument, and may refresh his memory by reference to notes.
A Member is allowed to read his speech during debates on the Appropriation Bill.
A Member must confine his observation to the subject under discussion and may not introduce any matter irrelevant thereto.
Reference shall not be made to any matter on which a judicial decision is pending, in such a way as might in Mr. SpeakerÆs opinion, prejudice the interest of parties, thereto.

Any Member deviating from the provisions of these Rules may be immediately called to order by Mr. SpeakerÆs or the Chairman. A Member raising a point of Order shall simply direct the attention to the point he desires to bring to Notice and submit it to Mr. Speaker or the Chairman for decision.

When the question of Order has been stated, the Member who raises it shall resume his seat, and no other Member except with the leave of Mr. Speaker or Chairman shall rise until the Speaker or Chairman has decided the question, after which the Member who was addressing the House or Committee at the time the question was raised shall be entitled to proceed with his speech giving effect to the ruling from the Chair.

fields.rule_subsection_title: TIME LIMIT AND SEQUENCE OF SPEECHES
fields.rule_details: The Rules and Business Committee shall allocate time to all Motions or Bills coming before the House.

fields.rule_subsection_title: TIME LIMIT AND SEQUENCE OF SPEECHES
fields.rule_details: During debates on all Motions or Bills, the Speaker shall allow speeches for the proposal first, followed by speeches against the proposal.

fields.rule_subsection_title: TIME LIMIT AND SEQUENCE OF SPEECHES
fields.rule_details: The Speaker shall allocate one-half to debate in favour of such proposition, and one-half to debate in opposition to such preposition.

fields.rule_subsection_title: TIME LIMIT AND SEQUENCE OF SPEECHES
fields.rule_details: No Member shall be entitled to address the House or a Committee of the Whole House for more than thirty minutes on any subject.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: During a sitting, all Members shall enter or leave the House with decorum.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: A Member shall not cross the floor of the House unnecessarily or sit in a place allotted to another Member.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Members shall not read newspapers in their places and shall only read such books and letters as may be connected with the business under debate.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: During a sitting, all Members shall be silent or shall confer only in undertones.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Members shall not make unseemly interruptions while any Member is speaking.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: No Member shall be allowed to smoke, chew or drink on the floor of the House

fields.rule_subsection_title: BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS IN THE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: Members shall attend the sittings of the House properly dressed.
Debate upon any Motion, Bill or Amendment shall be relevant to such Motion, Bill or Amendment except in the case of a substantive Motion for the Adjournment of the House.

When a Motion is made for Adjournment of a debate of the House during any debate, or that the Chairman do report progress or do leave he Chair, the debate upon such Motion shall be confined to the matter of such Motion; and a Member who has made or seconded such a Motion shall not be entitled to move or second any similar Motion during the same debate.

When an Amendment proposes to leave out words and insert other words, instead therefore, debate upon the first question proposed on the Amendment may include both the words proposed to be left out and those proposed to be inserted.
On an Amendment proposing to leave out words or to insert other words, debate shall be confined to the omission or insertion of such words, respectively.
No dilatory Motion shall be entertained by the Speaker.

After a question has been proposed, a Member rising  in  his  place may  claim  to  move  ôThat  the 
question be now putö, and unless it shall appear to the Chair that such Motion is an abuse of the Rules of the House or an infringement of the rights of the minority, the Motion ôThat the question be now putö shall be put forthwith and decided without Amendment or debate, notwithstanding that the mover has no opportunity to make his reply.

When the Motion ôThat the question be now putö has been carried, and the question consequent thereon has been decided, any further Motion may be made (if the assent of the Chair has not been withheld), which may be requisite to bring to a decision any question already proposed from the Chair.
Such question shall be put forthwith and decided without Amendment or debate.

This Rule shall be put in force only when the House or, in Committee of the Whole House.  Mr. Speaker or the Deputy Speaker is in the Chair, provided that when the absence of Mr. Speaker has been announced under the Provision of Rule 7 (Duties of the Deputy Speaker), this Order may be put into force in the House when the Deputy Speaker is in the Chair.

A question for the closure of debate shall not be decided in the affirmative unless a Division be taken, it appears by the numbers declared from the Chair that not less than one-half of all the Members present voted in the majority in support of the Motion.
It shall be out of Order to make a Motion or move an Amendment dealing with the subject matter of a Bill or other Order of the Day appointed for consideration.
An Order of the Day, Notice of Motion or Amendment of which Notice has been given shall not be anticipated in a debate upon a Motion for the Adjournment of the House or in any other debate.

In determining whether a discussion is out of Order on the grounds of anticipation, regards shall be had by Mr. Speaker to the probability of the matter anticipated being brought before the House within a reasonable time.

fields.rule_subsection_title: MR. SPEAKER TO BE HEAD IN SILENCE
fields.rule_details: Whenever Mr. Speaker, or the Chairman, rises during a debate, any Member then speaking or offering to speak must sit down, and the House or the Committee shall be silent so that Mr. Speaker or the Chairman may be heard without interruption.

Mr.  Speaker in the  House and the  Chairman in any Committee shall be responsible for the observance of the Rules of Order in the House and Committee respectively and their decision upon any Point of Order shall not be open to appeal and shall not be reviewed by the House except upon a substantive Motion made after Notice.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Mr. Speaker or the Chairman, after having called the attention of the House, or of the Committee, to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance or tedious repetition either of his own arguments or of the arguments used by other Members in debates, may direct him to discontinue his speech.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Mr. Speaker, or the Chairman, shall order Members whose conduct are grossly disorderly to withdraw immediately from the House during the remainder of that dayÆs sitting, and the Sergeant-At-Arms shall act on such orders. But if on any occasion, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman, deem that his powers, under the provisions of these Rules, are inadequate, he may name such Member or Members, in which event the same procedure shall be followed as is prescribed by paragraphs (3), (4), (5) and (6) of this Rule.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Whenever a Member shall have been named Mr. Speaker, or by the Chairman, immediately after the commission of the offence of disregarding an authority of the Chair, or of persistently and willfully obstructing the business of the House by abusing the Rules of the House, or otherwise,  then if the offence has been committed by such Member in the House, Mr. Speaker shall forthwith put the question on a Motion being made, Amendment, or debate being allowed:  ôThat such Member be suspended from the service of the Houseö and if the offence has been committed in a  Committee of the Whole House, the Chairman shall forthwith suspend the proceedings of the Committee and report the circumstances to the House; and Mr. Speaker shall on a  Motion being made forthwith put the same question, no Amendment, or debate being allowed as if the offence has been committed in the House itself.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Not more than one member shall be named at the same time, unless two or more members present together, have jointly disregarded the authority of the Chair.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: If a Member be suspended under the provision of this Rule, he shall be directed by Mr. Speaker to withdraw.  His suspension shall last until determined by the House.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details:
If a Member, or two or more Members acting jointly, who have been suspended under this Rule from the service of the House, shall refuse to obey the direction of Mr. Speaker to withdraw, when severally summoned under the direction, Mr Speaker shall call the attention of the House to the fact that recourse to force is necessary in order to compel obedience to his direction.

When the member or Members named by him as having refused to obey his direction have been removed from the House, they shall thereupon without any further question being put be suspended from the service of the House during the remainder of the session.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Members who are ordered to withdraw under paragraph (2) of this Rule or who are suspended from the service of the  House under paragraphs (3) and (6) of this Rule, shall forthwith withdraw from the precinct of the  House for the remainder of the sitting or the period of their suspension as the case may be.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: In the case of grave disorder arising in the  House, Mr. Speaker may if he thinks it necessary to do so, adjourn the House without putting any question.

fields.rule_subsection_title: ORDER IN THE HOUSE OR COMMITTEE
fields.rule_details: Nothing in this Rule shall be taken to deprive the House of the power of proceeding against any Member according to any Resolution of the   House.
No member may speak on any question after the same has been fully put by Mr. Speaker or the Chairman.
A question   is fully put   when Mr. Speaker  or the Chairman has collected the voices both of the ôAyesö and the ôNaysö

When the question has been put by Mr. Speaker or the Chairman at the conclusion of the debate, the votes shall be taken by voices æAyeÆ and ôNayö, and provided that no  Member then claims a   division, the result shall be declared by Mr. Speaker or the Chairman.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: If in the opinion of Mr. Speaker, or Committee  of the Whole House, the  Chairman  as  to  the decision   of the question is challenged, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall direct that the lobbies be cleared, and  on such direction being given, the doors of the lobby shall be locked and the division bell shall be rung for one minute.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: After the lapse of two minutes from the directives to clear the lobby,  Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall put the question a second time and if his opinion is again challenged, he shall direct that a Division be taken.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The Sergeant-at-Arms shall be responsible for making arrangements for the locking and unlocking of the doors.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: As soon as possible after the direction to clear the lobbies has been given, the Division Clerks appointed by the Clerk of the House shall call the names of all members in alphabetical order.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: A member may vote in a  division although he did not hear the question put but no Member is obliged to vote.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
1. A Member must vote according to his voice or
  2. Signing of register in a Division; or
  3. Through electronic voting installed in the House.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: If a member states that he voted in error or that his vote has been counted wrongly, he may claim to have this altered, provided that such request is made as soon as Mr. Speaker, or in Committee, the  Chairman has announced the numbers and before he shall have declared the result of the division.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details:
A Member shall not vote on any subject in which he has a direct personal pecuniary interest but a Motion to disallow a memberÆs vote on this ground shall be made only as soon as the number of the members voting on the question shall have been declared. If the Motion for the disallowance of a MemberÆs vote shall be agreed to, Mr. Speaker, or in Committee, the Chairman, shall direct the Clerk to correct the numbers voting in the Division accordingly.

In deciding whether a Motion for the disallowance of MemberÆs vote shall be proposed from the Chair, Mr. Speaker or in Committee, the Chairman, shall have regard to the character of the question upon which the Division was taken and to the consideration whether the interest therein of the Member whose vote is challenged is direct and pecuniary, or whether his vote was given on a matter of State policy.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: As soon as the Clerk has collected the votes. Mr. Speaker, or in Committee of the Whole House, the Chairman shall state the number of members voting for the  ôAyesö and ôNaysö respectively, and shall then declare the result of the Division.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS IN THE HOUSE AND COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In the event of the numbers being equal, Mr. Speaker or the Chairman may give a Casting vote, but if he does not do so, the question shall pass in the negative and Mr. Speaker or the Chairman shall so declare accordingly.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In Committee other than Committee of the Whole  House, a  Division shall be taken by Secretary to the  Committee asking each Member of the Committee separately how he desires to vote and recording the votes accordingly.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: In taking the division, the names of all Members of the Committee shall be called in alphabetical order.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: When a Division is claimed in a Committee other than a Committee of the Whole House, every Member of the Committee present shall, unless he expressly states that he declines to vote, record his vote for the ôAyesö or ôNaysö.  The Secretary to the Committee shall enter in the minutes of the Proceedings the record of each MemberÆs vote and shall add a statement of the names of the Members who decline to vote.  A Member must vote according to his voice.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: As soon as the Chairman shall state the numbers of Members voting for the ôAyesö and ôNaysö respectively, he shall then declare the result of the Division.  In the event of an equality of votes, the Chairman may, where he has casting vote, give that vote.  If no casting vote is given, the question passes in the negative.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: If a Member of Committee states that he voted in error or that his vote has been counted wrongly, he may claim to have his vote altered, provided that such request is made as soon as the Chairman has announced the numbers and before he shall declare the result of the Division.

fields.rule_subsection_title: DIVISIONS OF COMMITTEE OTHER THAN THE WHOLE HOUSE
fields.rule_details: The provision of paragraph (8) of Rule 40 (Division in the   House and   Committee of the    Whole House) shall apply to Divisions under this Rule as they apply to Divisions in the House.

Notice of presentation of a Government Bill shall be given by publication of the provisions proposed to be embodied in such Bill in an issue of the Official Gazette or House Journal of which a copy shall have been sent to every Member.

Any Member who wishes to move for leave to bring in a Bill shall give Notice of such Motion by sending a copy of the provisions to be embodied in the Bill to the Clerk, who shall cause them to be published in three successive issues of the Official Gazette or House Journal or the Order Paper and shall send a copy of the first of such issues to every Member.
1. All Bills emanating from the Governor shall be forwarded to the Speaker under covering letter personally signed by the Governor of Edo State.
Bills from Members shall also be forwarded to the Speaker.
The Speaker shall cause such Bills to be numbered and published in the ôSchedule of Billsö.
A printed copy of the Bill shall as soon as possible be sent to every Member.
On receipt of the Bill from the Speaker, the Rules and Business Committee shall Schedule the Bill for the First Reading.
Upon the short title of the Bill being read aloud by the Clerk, the Bill shall be deemed to have been read the first time.

fields.rule_subsection_title: APPOINTMENT DAYS FOR STAGES OF BILLS
fields.rule_details: Every Bill shall receive three  Readings previous to its passage, which Readings shall be on three different days unless the House unanimously directs otherwise and the Speaker shall give Notice at each Reading whether it is First, Second or Third.

fields.rule_subsection_title: APPOINTMENT DAYS FOR STAGES OF BILLS
fields.rule_details: At the conclusion of the proceedings on the First Reading or any subsequent stage of a Bill, a day to be named by the Committee on Rules and Business shall be appointed for the next stage.

On the Order for the Second Reading of a Bill being read, a Motion may be made ôthat the Bill be now read a Second timeö and a debate may arise covering the general merits and principles of the Bills.

On the Second Reading of a Bill, an Amendment may be proposed without Notice to the question ôthat the Bill be now read a second timeö to leave out the word ônowö and add at the end of the question ôupon this day . . .  monthsö or an Amendment may be moved to leave out all the words after the word ôthatö in order to add words stating the object and motive on which the opposition to the Bill is based, but such words must be strictly relevant to the principles of the Bill and not deal with its details.

When a  Bill has been read a second time,  it shall stand committed to a Standing Committee, unless the House on Motion made, commits it to the Committee of the Whole House. Such Motion shall not require Notice, but must be made immediately after the Bill is read a second time and must be proposed by the Majority Leader of the House. Bills committed to Standing Committees shall be allocated to a particular Committee by the Speaker whose discretion in this matter is final.

A Bill touching on the jurisdiction of two or more Committees shall be referred to the Committee having dominant jurisdiction.  The other Committees affected shall be constituted into Sub-Committees thereof for the purpose of considering and reporting to the main Committee, aspects of the Bill affecting their Committees.
The Committee to which a Bill has been committed shall report to the House after consideration of the Bill with Amendments (if any), it proposes to it.
Upon the report of the Standing Committees on a Bill not objected to by the House, it shall be placed on the House Calendar.
Bills placed on the Calendar shall be considered at a date to be determined by the Committee on Rules and Business.
A Bill committed to the Committee of the Whole House, after the Second Reading may be taken forthwith or on a   further day as may be determined by the Committee on Rules and Business.

Any Committee to which a Bill is committed shall have the power to make such Amendment therein as it shall be relevant to the subject matter of the Clause to which it relates; but if any such Amendments shall not be within the title of the Bill, they shall amend the title accordingly, and shall report the same specially to the House.
Any  Amendment proposed to the  Bill of which  Notice has not been given shall be handed to the Chairman in writing.

No Amendment shall be moved which is inconsistent with any Clause already agreed upon or any decision already come to by the Committee, and the Chairman may at any time during the discussion of proposed Amendment, withdraw it from the consideration of the Committee if, in his opinion, the discussion shall have shown that the Amendment violates the provisions of this Rule.
All Amendments having been considered, the Committee Chairman shall report to the House on a date scheduled by the Rules and Business Committee.

The Chairman of the Committee shall call the number of each  Clause in succession or the first and last number of a  group of  Clauses and if no Amendment be offered thereto or when all proposed Amendments shall have been disposed of, shall proceed to put the question, ôthat the Clause (or the Clause as amended) stand part of the Billö.

Amendment shall be moved which is inconsistent with any Clause already agreed upon or any decision already come to by the Committee, and the Chairman may at any time during the discussion of a proposed amendment, withdraw it from the consideration of the Committee if, in his opinion, the discussion shall have shown that the Amendment violates the provisions of the Rule.
A Clause may be postponed, unless upon an Amendment, thereto, a question shall have been fully put from the Chair.
Postponed Clauses shall be considered after the remaining Clauses of the Bill have been considered and before new Clauses are brought up.

When every Clause and schedule and proposed new Clause or Schedule had been dealt with, the preamble, if there be one, shall be considered and the question put ôthat this preamble (as amended) be the preamble to the Billö, provided that there is no further Amendment to the Billö.

If any Amendment be necessary to the title of a  Bill, it shall be made at the beginning of the proceedings detailed above,  but no question shall be put that the title or that the title as amended stands part of the Bill. At the conclusion of the proceedings, the Chairman shall put the question ôthat I do report the Bill (or the Bill as amended) to the Houseö, which question shall be decided without Amendment or debate.

When a Bill has been reported from a Committee of the Whole House, it shall be ordered to be read the third time forthwith or upon such day as the Rules and Business Committee may appoint, but if a Member gives notice of his intention to move the re-committal of the Bill in accordance with the next following paragraph of this Rule, a Bill may not be read the Third time until such time as the Motion for Re-Committal has been disposed of.

When a Bill has been ordered for Third Reading, any Member who may wish to amend or delete any provisions contained in the Bill or introduce any fresh provisions may give Notice of his intention, on the Order for Third Reading being read, to move ôthat the Bill be recommittedö. If such Motion be agreed to, the House shall resolve itself into Committee immediately or upon such day as the Rules and Business Committee may appoint.

When the Bill has been reported, the House shall then proceed with the Third Reading of the Bill unless the Rules and Business Committee decides to postpone this stage to a later day.

When a Bill has been the subject of a special report from a Standing Committee, the Chairman in charge of the Bill may on Notice given, move ôthat the Bill be recommitted to the Standing Committeeö. On this question being proposed, the House may delete the special Report from Standing Committee.
On the Third Reading of a Bill, a similar Amendment may be proposed to the question that the Bill, be now read the Third timeö as may be proposed on the Second Reading.

Amendments for the corrections, error permission, be made before the question for the Third Reading of the Bill is put from the Chair, but no Amendments of a material character shall be proposed and on this point, Mr. SpeakerÆs decision shall be final.

1. When a Bill has been passed by the House, a clean copy certified by the Clerk of the House, shall as soon as possible be presented to the Governor of Edo State of Nigeria for his assent.
  2. Where the Governor either withholds assent to a Bill or does not communicate his asset or otherwise within 30 days from the date the Bill was sent to him for assent, the Bill shall become Law if passed by the House of Assembly by two-third majority and the assent of the Governor shall not be required.

The Member in charge of a Bill may make a Motion with Notice for its withdrawal either before the commencement of public business or on the Order of the day for any stage of the Bill being read, provided the consent of the House is obtained.

fields.rule_subsection_title: BILLS OF THE SAME SUBJECT MATTER
fields.rule_details: More than one Bill of the same subject matter may be Introduced, but when the Second Reading of a Bill has been agreed to or negatived, the question shall not be proposed for the Second Reading of another Bill of the same subject matter during the same session. On the Order of the day relating to such Bill being read, Mr. Speaker shall direct that the Bill be withdrawn.

If it appears to Mr. Speaker from the Notice of the Terms proposed to be embodied in a Bill not being a Government measure, that the proposals are intended to affect or benefit some particular person, association or corporate body then:
  1. Before allowing such a Bill to be read the first time, Mr. Speaker shall satisfy himself that, in addition to the Notices already presented under Rule 42 (Notice regarding Bills), additional Notice of the Bill has been given by advertising a statement of its general nature and objects in the Official Gazette and in one newspaper circulating in Nigeria.
  2. When any such Bill has been read a Second time, it shall stand referred to a Committee without question being put. Any party whose interests are in Mr. SpeakerÆs opinion prejudicially affected by the proposed provisions of the Bill may be heard before the Committee either in person or by Counsel.
  3. Every Select Committee on such a Bill shall require proof of the facts and other allegations set forth in the Bill as showing that it is expedient that the Bill should be passed, and may take such oral or other evidence as it may think requisite, Therefore, if the Committee finds that the said facts and allegations are not proved, it shall report accordingly; but if the Committee finds that the said facts and allegations have been proved, the Committee shall consider the several Clauses of the Bill, and may strike out Clauses, add new Clauses, and make any other Amendments which it shall deem necessary in respect of all Amendments which it makes shall describe their support in a special report to the House. No new Clause shall be allowed in such a Bill which is outside the terms of the Notice in the Official Gazette.
  4. When it is intended to examine any witness, the Petitioner or Member of the House requiring such witnesses shall deliver to the Clerk, two days at least before the day appointed for their examination, a list containing the name, residence and occupation of every witness.
  5. The evidence of every witness shall be taken down and when printed, sent in proof to the witness. The witness shall be at liberty to suggest corrections due to inaccurate reporting and the evidence shall be printed with such of the corrections as may be approved by the Chairman.
  6. The Committee may at its discretion refuse to hear any irrelevant or recalcitrant witness.
  7. After the Report of the Select Committee has been presented to the House, Mr. Speaker shall, if such Report be adopted, propose the question ôthat the Bill be read the Third Timeö.

1. During each year, there shall be introduced into the House, an Appropriation Bill which shall contain the estimated financial requirements for expenditure on revenue accounts on all the services of the government for the succeeding financial year. The details of these financial requirements shall be contained in the Estimates which shall be presented at the same time.
  2. On presentation, the Bill shall be deemed to have been read the first time and a date shall be fixed for commencement of the Second Reading.
  3. During each year, there shall be introduced into the House a Finance Bill which shall contain all sources of revenue expected by the State to meet its anticipated expenditure.

The Rules and Business Committee shall determine the number of days to be allocated for the Second Reading of the Bill.  At the hour appointed for interruption of business on the last of such allotted days, Mr. Speaker shall put the question to bring the proceeding on the Second Reading to a conclusion, provided that the question on Second Reading may be agreed to on a day earlier than the last day so allotted.

During the Second Reading, the debate shall be confined to the financial and economic state of Edo State and the Government Financial Policy.  Detailed items in the estimates may not be debated on the Second Reading.

1. When the Bill has been read the Second time, it shall be committed to the Appropriation Committee. The Standing Committees of the House shall for this purpose be deemed to be Sub-Committees of the Appropriation Committee and shall consider estimates for the Ministries, Departments and Agencies which come under this charge.
  2. After consideration, the Sub-Committees shall report back to the Appropriation Committee. The Appropriation Committee, after deliberating on the Report of the Sub-Committees, shall then report to the Committee of the Whole House to be known as ôCommittee of Supplyö.
Mr. Speaker or in his absence, the Deputy Speaker shall preside over the Committee of Supply.
There shall be allotted such number of days as the Rules and Business Committee shall determine for discussion of the Estimates and the Appropriation Bill in the Committee of Supply.
The Clauses of an Appropriation Bill or a Supplementary Appropriation Bill shall stand postponed until after the consideration of any Schedule to such Bill.

On the consideration of the First Schedule, Mr. Speaker shall call the title of each Head of Expenditure in turn and shall propose the question ôthat the sum of naira for that àà stand part of the Schedule".
Any Member may move an Amendment to the provisions in the Estimates.

When several Amendments are proposed to the same provisions in the Estimates, they shall be called in the order in which they appear on the Order Paper and each Amendment shall be disposed of before the next is called, provided that when the mover of the Amendments is not present to move it, the same shall lapse.
At least two clear days Notice of any Amendments shall be required.
When all Amendments to a Sub-Head or item have been disposed of, no further Amendment or debate on the same shall be allowed.

When all Amendments standing on the Order Paper in respect of a particular provision have been disposed of, Mr. Speaker shall propose the question ôthat the sum of à. Naira for head à.. Stand part of the Schedule".

At the hour appointed for the interruption of business on the last day allotted for the consideration of the Appropriation Bill in the Committee of Supply, the Chairman shall proceed to put any question on any Head not yet voted on and the question ôthat the Schedule or Schedules stand part of the Billö.

On the question of the postponed Clauses of the Bill, no Amendment shall be allowed other than an Amendment consequential on any increase or decrease in the total sum appropriated by any Schedule. Such Amendment shall be put from the Chair without Motion made and no debate shall be allowed on any such question or Amendment.
After the Third Reading, the laid down procedures for Bills shall be followed.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee of Selection appointed at the commencement of every Session to perform the functions allocated to it by these Rules and for such other matters as the House may from time to time refer to it.
  2. The Committee of Selection shall consist of the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker and Nominees of the Political Parties in accordance with their numerical strength in the House.
  3. The Speaker shall be Chairman of the Committee on Selection and in his absence, the Deputy Speaker.
  4. The CommitteeÆs functions shall include:
    1. Nominating Members to serve on any Ad-hoc Special Committees to consider any special matter brought before the House; and
    2. Such Members as may be going on Parliamentary Delegations other than Committees.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Rules and Business Committee appointed at the commencement of the life of the House consisting of five Members nominated by the Political Parties represented in the House in accordance with their numerical strength.
  2. The functions of the Rules and Business Committee shall include:
    1. Scheduling the business of the House and causing them to be printed on the Order Paper.
    2. Allocation of time for the business of the House.
    3. House organization relative to Rules and Procedure of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the House Services Committee appointed at the commencement of the life of the House to look after the welfare of Members; which shall functions thus:
    1. Procurement of materials or commodities necessary for the comfort of Members;
    2. Provision and maintenance of utilities other than those provided as public utilities by government for the welfare of Members, save that it shall exclude those in the Office Complex of the House of Assembly;
    3. Liaise with such persons, or organizations to ensure measures which are necessary for the well-being of Members;
    4. Shall look after the health of Members and their families.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Public Petitions Committee consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The Committee shall consider the subject matters of the petitions referred to it under the provisions of Rule 16 (Petitions) and shall report from time to time to the House their opinions of the action to be taken thereon, together with such other observations on the petitions and the signatures attached thereto as the Committee may think fit.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details: 1. There shall be a Committee to be known as Public Accounts Committee consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Tenders Board Committee consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the House. This Committee shall be headed by the Deputy Speaker of the House.
  2. The Committee shall handle major supplies, purchases and other capital intensive projects of the House in accordance with due process.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details: The House may appoint any other Special Committee to perform such duties as the need may arise.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as Committee on Agriculture consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Agriculture generally;
    2. Agriculture College and Experiment Stations;
    3. Agriculture Education Extension Services;
    4. Agriculture Economics and Research;
    5. Agriculture Production, Marketing and Stabilization of prices of Agricultural Products and Commodities (not including distribution outside of Nigeria.
    6. Animal Industry and Soil Conservation;
    7. Crop Insurance and Soil Conservation;
    8. Diary Industry;
    9. Etymology and Plant Quarantine;
    10. Extension of Farm Credit and Farm Security;
    11. Forestry in general, and Forest Reserves;
    12. Inspection of Livestock and Meat Products;
    13. Plant Industry, Soils and Agricultural Engineering;
    14. Commodities Exchanges;
    15. Rural Development;
    16. Budget Proposal.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATION AND PROJECT MONITORING)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Appropriation and Project Monitoring consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover;
    1. Appropriation of revenue for the support of the Government.
    2. Rescission of appropriation contained in the Appropriation Law. The Committee shall include separate headings for ôRescissionsö and Transfers of unexpended Balancesö in any Bill or Resolution as reported from the Committee under its jurisdiction specified in Sub-paragraph (b) or (c), with all proposed rescissions or transfers in the accompanying Committee Report.
    3. ADDITIONAL FUNCTIONS OF THE COMMITTEE
      1. The Committee on Appropriations shall, within thirty days after the transmittal of the Budget to the House each year, hold hearings on the Budget as a whole with particular reference to:
        1. The basic recommendations and budgetary policies of the Governor in the presentation of the Budget; and
        2. The fiscal, financial and economic assumption used as bases in arriving at total estimated expenditures and receipts.
      2. In holding hearings pursuant to Sub-division 3(1)(a):
        1. The Committee shall receive testimony from the Commissioner of Finance, the Director of Budget and such other persons as the Committee may desire.
        2. Hearings pursuant to Sub-division (3(1)(a) or any part thereof, shall be held in Open Session and with a quorum present determines by recall vote that the testimony to be taken at that hearing on that day may be related to a matter to State Security; provided, however, that the Committee may by the same procedure choose one subsequent day of hearing. A transcript of all such hearings shall be printed and a copy thereof furnished to each Member.
  4. In addition, the Committee on Appropriation shall study on a continuing basis, those provisions of law which (on the first day of the first fiscal year for which the House of Assembly budget process is effective), provided spending authority or permanent budget authority and shall report to the House from time to time its recommendations for terminating or codifying such provisions.
    5.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON FINANCE ON AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Finance and Economic Development Committee, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall recover:
    1. The Budget Proposals;
    2. The Finances of the State.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Commerce and Industry consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall include:
    1. Commerce in the State generally;
    2. Measures to foster commercial intercourse with other States;
    3. Consumer affairs and consumer protection;
    4. Industries set up by the Edo State Government;
    5. Assistance to and protection of small businesses including financial aid.
    6. Annual budget estimates

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Education consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall include:
    1. Measures relating to education, generally
    2. Annual budget estimates

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND TRANSPORT)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Environment and Transport consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Oversight of the State Ministry Responsible for Environment and Transport;
    2. Control of Industrial, Toxic and Other Hazardous Waste;
    3. Environmental Sanitation, and Pollution;
    4. Measures Relating to Inland Waterways;
    5. Traffic Regulations and Roads Safety Codes;
    6. Annual Budget.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON JUDICIARY, HUMAN RIGHTS AND LEGAL MATTERS)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Judiciary, Human Rights and Legal Matters, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Judicial Matters generally;
    2. State Courts and Judges;
    3. Magistrates and Judges of Customary Courts;
    4. Measures relating to claims against the State;
    5. Revision and Certification of State Laws;
    6. Constitutional Matters;
    7. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Health, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Hospitals and Clinics established by the State;
    2. Drug Manufacturing;
    3. Sanitation Laws;
    4. Food and Environmental Hygiene;
    5. Drug Laws;
    6. Epidemics;
    7. Budget.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION, YOUTHS AND SPORTS)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Information, Youth and Sports, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Information dissemination generally;
    2. The State Radio and Television Services;
    3. The State Publishing Corporation;
    4. Youth Movement;
    5. Sporting Activities;
    6. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND CHIEFTAINCY AFFAIRS)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Local Government and Chieftaincy Affairs, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Monitoring the functions of Local Government Councils in the State;
    2. Liaising with the Office of the Deputy Governor on Chieftaincy matters.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON OIL AND GAS)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Oil and Gas, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Matters relating to mineral exploration such mining and the utilization of funds for mineral producing areas.
    2. Gas and allied matters generally including natural gas and its derivatives, exploited within the State.
    3. Fostering of Community and Mining, and Petroleum Exploring Companies Relations.
    4. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON WOMEN AFFAIRS AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Women Affairs and Social Development, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. The promotion and general welfare of women and their social, political and economic participation in all aspects of the development of the State.
    2. The health of women and children as well as women vocational training.
    3. Child development.
    4. Assistance to vulnerable segments of the society including the disabled and handicapped.
    5. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON WORKS AND PUBLIC UTILITIES)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Works and Public Utilities, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Measures relating to the construction and maintenance of State roads and budgets, including traffic regulations and roads safety codes.
    2. Public Buildings including the House of Assembly Complex.
    3. Oversight of the Ministry responsible for Works and Public Utilities related matters such as Light and Water, except those functions already assigned to other Committee (s).
    4. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON ETHICS AND PRIVILEGES)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Ethics and Privileges, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Matters relating to the Code of Conduct of Members.
    2. To recommend to the House from time to time, such administrative measures as it may deem appropriate to establish or enforce as standards of Code of Conduct for Members, amongst others.
    3. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON LANDS AND SURVEY)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Lands and Survey, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. Matters relating to Land Use and Allocation.
    2. Urban and Country Planning.
    3. Oversight of the Ministry responsible for Lands and Survey.
    4. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON ARTS AND CULTURE)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Arts and Culture, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. The oversight of the Ministry responsible for Arts, Culture and Tourism.
    2. (b)All Parastatals under the Ministry except such as assigned to other Committee(s).
    3. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as Committee on Security, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. To liaise with relevant security agencies in the State to design and implement adequate security measures in the State.
    2. To design and implement pre-emptive measures on security of the residential quarters of Members and periodically alert on perceived threat or security.
    3. To address other such matter as may in the course of their assignment be referred to it.
    4. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: STANDING COMMITTEE (COMMITTEE ON ENERGY AND WATER RESOURCES)
fields.rule_details:
1. There shall be a Committee to be known as the Committee on Energy and Water Resources, consisting of five Members appointed at the commencement of the life of the House.
  2. The CommitteeÆs jurisdiction shall cover:
    1. To liaise with relevant security agencies in the State to design and implement adequate security measures in the State.
    2. To design and implement pre-emptive measures on security of the residential quarters of Members and periodically alert on perceived threat or security.
    3. To address other such matter as may in the course of their assignment be referred to it.
    4. Annual budget estimates.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details: Members of Committees shall be nominated by the Political parties represented in the House, according to their numerical strength.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details: Mr. Speaker shall appoint the Chairman of Standing Committee, subject to the approval of the whole House.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_details: The Quorum at Committee sittings shall be two-thirds of the Membership, provided the Chairman or a person acting in that capacity is present.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: RULES OF PROCEDURES FOR COMMITTEES IN GENERAL
fields.rule_details: The Rules of the House are the Rules of its Committees and Sub-Committees so far as applicable, except in connection with a Motion of high privilege in Committees and Sub-Committees.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: RULES OF PROCEDURES FOR COMMITTEES IN GENERAL
fields.rule_details: Each Sub-Committee of a Committee is a part of the Committee and subject to its Rules as far as applicable.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: RULES OF PROCEDURES FOR COMMITTEES IN GENERAL
fields.rule_details: Each Committee is authorized at any time to consider such investigations and studies as it may consider necessary or appropriate in the exercise of its responsibilities under this Rule

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: RULES OF PROCEDURES FOR COMMITTEES IN GENERAL
fields.rule_details: Each Committee is authorized to have printed and bound testimony and other data presented at hearings held by the Committee.  All costs of stenographic services and transcripts in connection with any meeting or hearing of a Committee shall be paid from the contingency fund of the House.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEES OF THE HOUSE; ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES
fields.rule_subsection_title: RULES OF PROCEDURES FOR COMMITTEES IN GENERAL
fields.rule_details: Each Committee shall submit to the House, an annual report on the activities of that Committee under this Rule.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEE RULES, ADOPTION OF WRITTEN RULES
fields.rule_details:
Each Standing Committee of the House shall adopt written rules governing its procedures. Such rules:
  1. Shall be adopted in a meeting which is open to the public unless the Committee in open session and with a quorum present, determines by recall vote that all or part of the meeting on that day is to be closed to the public.
  2. Shall not be inconsistent with the Rules of the House or with those provisions of law having the force and effect of Rules of the House; and
  3. Shall, in any event, incorporate all of the succeeding provisions of this clause to the extent applicable. Each CommitteeÆs rules specifying its regular meeting days, and any other rules of a Committee, which are in addition to the provisions of this Clause, shall be published in the House of Assembly Records.
  4. Each Standing Committee of the House shall adopt regular meetings, which shall not be less frequent than monthly, for the conduct of its business. Each such Committee shall meet, for the consideration of any Bill or the transaction of other Committee business, on all regular meeting days fixed by the Committee, unless otherwise provided by written Rules adopted by the Committee.

fields.rule_section_title: COMMITTEE RULES, ADOPTION OF WRITTEN RULES
fields.rule_details:
The Chairman of each Standing Committee may call and convene, as he or she considers necessary, additional meetings of the Committee for the consideration of any Bill or Resolution pending before the Committee or for the conduct of other Committee business. The Committee shall meet for such purpose pursuant to that call of the Chairman.
  1. If at least three Members of any Standing Committee be called by the Chairman, those Members may file in the Office of the Committee, their written request to the Chairman for that special meeting.
